List of haunted locations in the Philippines

revision.text:
[[File:Santo Tomas.jpg|thumb|One of the principal buildings housing internees at the [[Santo Tomas Internment Camp]] was the Education building (now [[University of Santo Tomas|UST]] Hospital building). Shanties and vegetable gardens can be seen near the building and the wall of the university compound is in the background.]] There are several '''reportedly haunted locations in the [[Philippines]]'''. Reports of such haunted locations are part of [[ghostlore]], which is a form of [[folklore]]. The entries are alphabetized.
==Luzon== <!-- Note to editors: There is consensus that entries must cite external references or they will be removed. Entries should also be in alphabetical order. -->
===[[Metro Manila]]=== <!-- Note to editors: There is consensus that entries must cite external references or they will be removed. Entries should also be in alphabetical order. --> [[File:7876Balete Drive Quezon City Landmarks 30.jpg|thumb|left|Balete Drive]] [[File:Manila film center.jpg|thumb|left|Manila Film Center]] * '''[[Ateneo de Manila University]]''': One of the most prestigious educational institutions of the country, ADMU is claimed by believers to be haunted.<ref name="Rappler Ateneo">{{Cite news|author=|title=Spooky school stories: Ateneo edition|url=http://www.rappler.com/entertainment/42711-spooky-school-stories-ateneo-edition|accessdate=31 July 2016|publisher=Rappler.com|date=2 November 2013}}</ref><ref name="CNNPh10HPMM">{{cite web|url=http://cnnphilippines.com/life/culture/2016/10/28/10-haunted-places-list.html |title=I see dead people: 10 haunted places around Metro Manila |publisher=[[CNN Philippines]] |author=CNN Philippines Life Staff |date=28 October 2016 |accessdate=4 November 2017}}</ref> * '''[[Balete Drive]]''': A major residential [[List of roads in Metro Manila|avenue]] in the eastern part of New Manila, Quezon City, Balete Drive is noted as the site of several apparitions of a [[White Lady (ghost)|white lady]], who is considered by believers to be the ghost of a teenage girl who was raped and killed by a taxi driver in the 1950s.<ref name="CNNPh10HPMM" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.philippinesinsider.com/myths-folklore-superstition/myths-surrounding-balete-drive/|title=Myths Surrounding Balete Drive|work=Philippines Guide|accessdate=14 November 2010}}</ref><ref name="Philippine Daily Inquirer">{{cite news|author=Yap, Dj|title=Balete may be official "haunted" site|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=DlQ1AAAAIBAJ&sjid=aCUMAAAAIBAJ&pg=2820,122918&dq=balete+drive+white+lady&hl=en|accessdate=18 April 2012|publisher=Philippine Daily Inquirer|date=1 November 2005}}</ref><ref name="CasasGagatiga2011">{{cite book|author1=Dianne De Las Casas|author2=Zarah C. Gagatiga|title=Tales from the 7,000 Isles: Filipino Folk Stories|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7XY8TgcG7p0C&pg=PA119|accessdate=18 April 2012|date=30 September 2011|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-1-59884-698-0|pages=119–}}</ref><ref name="PhilStarMM"/> * '''[[De La Salle University]]''': Due to its brutal [[World War II|Second World War]]-era history (including the massacre of numerous refugees who sought shelter inside the [[Chapel of the Most Blessed Sacrament]]), DLSU is reportedly haunted.<ref name="CNNPh10HPMM" /><ref name="Rappler LaSalle">{{Cite news|author=|title=Spooky school stories: La Salle edition|url=http://www.rappler.com/life-and-style/42758-spooky-school-stories-la-salle-edition|accessdate=31 July 2016|publisher=Rappler.com|date=2 November 2013}}</ref> * '''[[Fort Santiago]]''': This is a historic fortress in [[Intramuros]], Manila, and said by believers to be haunted by ghosts of soldiers and civilian victims killed during World War II.<ref name="CNNPh10HPMM" /><ref name="HauntedAmericaTours" /><ref name="Buzzfeed2016" /> * '''[[Malacañang Palace]]''': The official residence and principal workplace of the [[President of the Philippines]] is considered by believers to be haunted by numerous ghosts such as former presidents, former presidential aides and attendants, those from [[History of the Philippines (900–1521)|pre-Hispanic]] and [[History of the Philippines (1521–1898)|Spanish eras]], as well as a black lady peering out towards the Pasig River from a window of the Mabini Hall late at night.<ref name="Buzzfeed2016" /><ref name="Rappler" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://malacanang.gov.ph/2684-undas-2012-malacanan-palace-prowlers-ghosts-elementals-and-other-phantasmagoric-tales/|title="Malacañan Palace Prowlers: Ghosts, elementals, and other phantasmagoric tales"|work=Presidential Museum & Library |accessdate=16 June 2013}}</ref><ref name="CNNPhConjuring" /> [[File:Manila Cityhall.jpg|thumb|Manila City Hall at night]] * '''[[Manila City Hall]]''': Believing city hall employees claim of wandering specters after 6:00 p.m. at night. Believers also indicate its eerie casket-like shape when viewed from above (although some contend it resembles the shield of the [[Knights Templar]]).<ref name="CNNPh10HPMM" /><ref name="PhilStarMM">{{cite news|author=Bolando, AJ|title=5 'creepiest, scariest' places in Metro Manila|url=http://www.philstar.com/news-feature/2013/10/29/1248991/5-creepiest-scariest-places-metro-manila|accessdate=30 July 2016|publisher=PhilStar.com|date=29 October 2013}}</ref><ref name="Rappler" /> * '''[[Manila Film Center]]''': A major component of the [[Cultural Center of the Philippines Complex|Cultural Center of the Philippines]], the facility was the site of a construction accident in 1981. When construction of the building was rushed for [[Manila Film Center#The First Manila Film Festival|a film festival]], the ceiling scaffolding collapsed, killing several workmen. Rather than halt construction to rescue survivors and retrieve the bodies of the dead workmen, First Lady [[Imelda Marcos]], the main financier of the project, was believed to have ordered cement to be poured into the orchestra, entombing the fallen workmen, some of whom were even buried alive. Various ghostly activities have been reported, including mysterious sounds, voices and [[poltergeist]] activity. In the late 1990s, a group called the Spirit Questors began to make visits to the film center, in an attempt to contact and appease the souls of the workmen who were killed in the building. Some of these spirits claimed to have moved on, but a few allegedly remain.<ref name="CNNPh10HPMM" /><ref name="PhilStarMM"/><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://gmapinoytv.igma.tv/sidetrip/blog/?/archives/42-The-Manila-Film-Center-mystery-A-ghostly-place-or-an-urban-legend.html/ |title=The Manila Film Center mystery: A ghostly place or an urban legend? |date=1 November 2005 |work=Sidetrip with Howie Severino |accessdate=14 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080603051032/http://gmapinoytv.igma.tv/sidetrip/blog/?%2Farchives%2F42-The-Manila-Film-Center-mystery-A-ghostly-place-or-an-urban-legend.html%2F |archivedate=3 June 2008 |df= }}</ref><ref name="PhilStarHauntedP">{{cite web |url= http://www.philstar.com/cebu-lifestyle/2015/11/01/1517174/haunted-places |title= Haunted places {{!}} Cebu Lifestyle, The Freeman Sections, The Freeman |author= Galan, Daniel Drake |website=PhilStar.com |publisher=[[Philippine Star]] |date=1 November 2015 |accessdate=15 November 2017}}</ref> The facility, formerly abandoned due to its reputation, is now in use after restoration works. * '''[[Miriam College]]''': Believing students claim of the ghost of a nun in the ladies' restroom at the 2nd floor of the Caritas Building.<ref>{{Cite web|author=Smitten, Get|url=http://pumpdown.com/20-most-haunted-places-in-the-philippines/19/|title=20 Most Haunted Places in the Philippines - Page 19 of 20|date=31 October 2015|work=PumpDown|accessdate=7 August 2016}}</ref> [[File:Ozone disco.jpg|thumb|200px|Ozone discothèque as it appeared in 2008.]] * '''[[Ozone Disco Club fire|Ozone Disco]]''': A former [[discothèque]] in [[Quezon City]] that was the site of the worst fire in the Philippine history. The fire killed at least 162 people and injured at least 95.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.geocities.com/angeloffools/stuff/ozone.html|title=The Ozone Disco Tether|last=Nepomuceno|first=Manny|date=12 October 2001|work=In Nomine Philippines|accessdate=14 November 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071022032048/http://www.geocities.com/angeloffools/stuff/ozone.html|archivedate=22 October 2007}}</ref><ref name=nyt2>{{cite news |author=Associated Press |title=Disco in Manila, for 35 People, Held 400 |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C07E2DA1739F933A15750C0A960958260 |work=New York Times Online |publisher=[[New York Times]] |date=20 March 1996 |accessdate=29 January 2008}}</ref><ref name=pnh>{{cite news |first=Sol Jose |last=Vanzi |title=LIGHT SENTENCES FOR OZONE DISCO OWNERS |url=http://www.newsflash.org/2001/03/hl/hl013279.htm |work=Newsflash |publisher=Philippine Headline News Online |date=12 March 2001 |accessdate=29 January 2008}}</ref><ref name=nyt1>{{cite news |author=[[Associated Press]] |title=At Least 150 Are Killed in Disco Fire in Manila |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C04E2DC1739F93AA25750C0A960958260 |work=New York Times Online |publisher=[[New York Times]] |date=19 March 1996 |accessdate=29 January 2008}}</ref> The discothèque building was demolished in 2015, and the site is now presently occupied by GoodAh!!!, a 24-hour diner, co-operated by [[Boy Abunda]], and paranormal activities in the area were claimed to have greatly minimized ever since.<ref name="Rappler" /><ref name="PhilStarHauntedP"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/focus/02/17/15/last-look-ozone-disco|title=LAST LOOK: Ozone Disco|author= Fernando G. Sepe, Jr. |date=17 February 2015|work=ABS-CBN News|accessdate=14 April 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.pep.ph/lifestyle/food/34017/remember-the-former-ozone-disco-its-now-a-food-chain-owned-by-boy-abunda?ref=latest_feed_1|title=Remember the former Ozone Disco? It's now a food chain owned by Boy Abunda|publisher=[[Philippine Entertainment Portal]]|last=Llanera|first=Melba|date=October 13, 2016|accessdate=October 13, 2016}}</ref> * '''[[Philippine National Bank|PNB]] Branch [[Pasay]]''': The fifth floor of this Pasay branch of PNB at [[Roxas Boulevard]] was used as a morgue for the 16-to-25 victims of a fire at the Regent of Manila hotel on February 13, 1985. Exorcisms were conducted on the said floor at the requests of previous occupants because of frequent paranormal activities.<ref name="CNNPh10HPMM" /> * '''[[Polytechnic University of the Philippines]]''': The institution's Claro M. Recto Hall houses a theater where the backstage rooms are the hot spots of an apparition of a burnt entity as confirmed by theater director and professor Segundo "Dodie" Dizon. The College of Engineering is also a paranormal hotspot where not only a ghost of a child and a white lady are said to appear but also the spirit of a deceased professor frequents the halls. [[ABS-CBN]] telemagazine program [[Magandang Gabi, Bayan]] featured the paranormal case of PUP in its 2005 Halloween Special. * '''[[Robinsons Galleria]]''': Most female shoppers avoided its department store in the 1980s because of rumors about a half-human, half-snake creature residing in the basement of the mall.<ref name="PhilStarMM"/> * '''Starmall Alabang''': It is situated on the former site of the Alabang Cemetery. Believers claim ghosts haunting its theaters.<ref name="CNNPh10HPMM" /><ref name="PhilStarMM"/><ref name="HauntedAmericaTours" /> * '''[[University of the Philippines]] [[University of the Philippines Diliman|Diliman Campus]]''': Its long history is said to be the reason of its alleged hauntings. Some of the areas of reported paranormal activity include the College of Music, the Vanguard Building, and Palma Hall. Guerrero Theater, which is housed in the second floor of Palma Hall, supposedly hosts the spirit of a young theater actress who committed suicide after a newcomer obscured her recognition.<ref name="CNNPh10HPMM" /><ref name="Rappler UP">{{Cite news|author=Occenola, Paige|title=Spooky school stories: UP Diliman edition|url=http://www.rappler.com/life-and-style/42725-spooky-school-stories-up-diliman-edition|accessdate=31 July 2016|publisher=Rappler|date=2 November 2013}}</ref> * '''[[University of Santo Tomas]]''': Is reported by believers to be haunted, due to its long history that spans from the Spanish era. Santo Tomas also served as an [[Santo Tomas Internment Camp|internment camp]] during the Second World War wherein many of the prisoners of war were "enemy aliens", mostly Americans, living in the Philippines. Many prisoners died of starvation, illness, and others. The university is also a witness to unlucky students resorting to suicide, such as the female ghost in one of the ladies' restrooms in the Main Building.<ref name="CNNPh10HPMM" /><ref name="Rappler" /><ref name="Buzzfeed2016" /> Former UST Rector Magnificus [[Rolando de la Rosa]] confirmed in an interview about an alleged mass grave located near the UST museum.
===[[Bataan]]=== <!-- Note to editors: There is consensus that entries must cite external references or they will be removed. Entries should also be in alphabetical order. --> * '''Ruins of Lazareto de Mariveles''': located at the heart of [[Mariveles, Bataan|Mariveles]], it was the first quarantine station that was bombed during the Japanese occupation.<ref name="gmapinoyshocker">{{cite web|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/publicaffairs/kapusomojessicasoho/204653/pinoy-shocker-philippines-most-haunted-places-laman-loob-campus-ghost-stories-and-halloween-business/story/|title="Pinoy Shocker, Philippines’ Most Haunted Places, Laman-Loob, Campus Ghost Stories, and Halloween Business!"|date=29 October 2010|publisher=[[GMA Network]]|accessdate=22 July 2018}}</ref>
===[[Benguet]]=== <!-- Note to editors: There is consensus that entries must cite external references or they will be removed. Entries should also be in alphabetical order. -->
====Baguio==== <!-- Note to editors: There is consensus that entries must cite external references or they will be removed. Entries should also be in alphabetical order. --> '''[[Baguio]]''', the largest city of [[Luzon|Northern Luzon]] and a noted tourist destination, is said to be highly haunted. There are several haunted locations scattered throughout the city, such as cemeteries, old hotels, and other sites where structures used to stand until the [[1990 Luzon earthquake]] destroyed them, injuring and killing the people inside. The city was also the site of some of the most brutal atrocities committed during [[World War II]].<ref name="HauntedAmericaTours">{{Cite web |author=Bagasbas, Rodrigo|url=http://www.hauntedamericatours.com/ghosthunting/phillipines.php|title=THE TOP TEN MOST HAUNTED SCARIEST PLACES IN THE PHILIPPINES|date=|work=Haunted America Tours|accessdate=31 July 2016}}</ref><ref name="Cabrera PDI">{{cite news |first=Vincent |last=Cabreza |title=Horror means profit |url=http://business.inquirer.net/money/features/view_article.php?article_id=97328 |publisher=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]] |date=28 October 2007 |accessdate=19 February 2008}}</ref><ref name="Choose PH Baguio">{{Cite web|author=Palma, Renzelle Ann|url=http://www.choosephilippines.com/specials/lists/794/baguio-haunted-spots/|title=Top 5 Baguio Haunted Spots|date=23 October 2013|website=Choose Philippines. Find. Discover. Share.|publisher=[[ABS-CBN Corporation]]|accessdate=12 December 2016}}</ref><ref name="Lakbay Baguio">{{Cite web|author=Vince|url=http://lakbaybaguio.com/2014/10/five-haunted-places-baguio-city/|title=Five Haunted Places In Baguio City|date=23 October 2014|publisher=LakbayBaguio|accessdate=12 December 2016}}</ref> Such haunted locations include the following: * '''[[Casa Vallejo]]''': The oldest hotel in the city, it was built in 1909 to house key personnel of the Bureau of Public Works, before becoming a hotel in 1923. It is alleged that it served as a detention center for the German prisoners of war in 1917.<ref name="Choose PH Baguio" /> * '''[[Dominican Hill Retreat House]]''': Commonly called '''Diplomat Hotel''', it was originally a seminary and later converted into a hotel. Situated atop the Dominican Hill, it has been considered as the city's most haunted location as it was the site of numerous atrocities committed by the [[Imperial Japanese Army|Japanese forces]] during World War II.<ref name="HauntedAmericaTours" /><ref name="PhilStarHauntedP"/><ref name="Choose PH Baguio" /><ref name="Lakbay Baguio" /> * '''[[Hyatt Terraces Hotel]]''': Was a 12-storey hotel that was destroyed in the [[1990 Luzon earthquake]]. The destruction killed at least 50 people. Believers claim ghosts of those perished in the earthquake wandering the vacant site.<ref name="Choose PH Baguio" /><ref name="Lakbay Baguio" /> * '''[[Laperal White House]]''': Also known as the Laperal Guesthouse, it was built by Roberto Laperal in the 1930s as a vacation home for his family. During World War II, the Japanese soldiers occupied the house and used it as a garrison, where they reportedly committed various atrocities, such as torturing and killing suspected spies working for the United States and their allies. Purchased in 2007 by one of the prominent [[Chinese Filipino|Filipino-Chinese]] business magnate billionaires, [[Lucio Tan]], it now serves as a museum of locally-made Filipino artworks based on bamboo and wood.<ref name="Buzzfeed2016" /><ref name="Lakbay Baguio" /><ref name="CNNPhConjuring" /> * '''[[Loakan Road]]''': The access road to [[Loakan Airport]], believers claim of a female [[vanishing hitchhiker]] (supposedly a rape victim) wandering the area.<ref name="Choose PH Baguio" /><ref name="Lakbay Baguio" /> * '''[[Philippine Military Academy]]''': The military school of the [[Armed Forces of the Philippines]] (AFP) is reportedly haunted by various ghosts, including phantom platoons marching in the parade grounds late at night.<ref name="HauntedAmericaTours" /> * '''[[Teacher's Camp]]''': First established as a training site by American teachers ([[Thomasites]]), it is now training center for teachers in the country. It is alleged that it was built on the site of a battlefield of the former indigenous residents.<ref name="HauntedAmericaTours" /><ref name="Buzzfeed2016" /><ref name="Choose PH Baguio" /><ref name="Lakbay Baguio" />
<gallery mode="packed"> Diplomat Hotel in Baguio City.JPG|Dominican Hill Retreat House Laperal House Facade.JPG|Laperal House Teacher's Camp.JPG|Teacher's Camp </gallery>
===[[Bulacan]]=== <!-- Note to editors: There is consensus that entries must cite external references or they will be removed. Entries should also be in alphabetical order. --> [[File:FvfBulacan8635 02.JPG|thumb|Bahay na Pula in 2014]] * '''[[Bahay na Pula]]''' (or Ilusorio Mansion): A [[World War II]] site in [[San Ildefonso, Bulacan|San Ildefonso]], which the [[Imperial Japanese Army]] used as their barracks and became a place where so-called local [[comfort women]] were forced to work.<ref name="CNNPhConjuring">{{cite web| url=http://cnnphilippines.com/life/entertainment/film/2016/06/09/philippine-haunted-houses.html |title=Conjuring the horrific histories of Philippine haunted houses |publisher=[[CNN Philippines]] |author=Gloria, Gaby |date=7 July 2017 |accessdate=4 November 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Doyo|first1=Maria Ceres|title=Remembering the ‘Bahay na Pula’|url=http://opinion.inquirer.net/92401/remembering-the-bahay-na-pula|accessdate=19 July 2016|publisher=Philippine Daily Inquirer|date=28 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|author=Smitten, Get|url=http://pumpdown.com/20-most-haunted-places-in-the-philippines/|title=20 Most Haunted Places in the Philippines|date=31 October 2015|work=PumpDown|accessdate=7 August 2016}}</ref> It was demolished in 2016 due to a feuding internal conflict between the current members of the Ilusorio family.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://lifestyle.inquirer.net/235337/ilusorio-house-symbol-of-japans-comfort-women-in-ph-demolished/|title=Ilusorio house, symbol of Japan’s comfort women in PH, demolished|author=Edgar Allan M. Sembrano|date=August 15, 2016}}</ref>
===[[Cavite]]=== <!-- Note to editors: There is consensus that entries must cite external references or they will be removed. Entries should also be in alphabetical order. --> [[File:IJVOldHospital1.jpg|thumb|left|Ruins of Corregidor's hospital, where sounds of footsteps and normal hospital activities have been heard.]] * '''[[Corregidor Island]]''': A historic island at the entrance of [[Manila Bay]] , Corregidor played a major role during [[World War II]], during the invasion and liberation of the Philippines from Japanese forces. The '''Malinta Tunnel''' was first used as a storage facility of the U.S. Army during World War II, but was later converted into a hospital where injured soldiers were treated.<ref name="Buzzfeed2016" /><ref name="Rappler" /><ref>{{Cite web|author=Aquino, James|url=https://www.tripzilla.com/12-real-haunted-places-in-philippines-terrify-the-hell-out-of-you/22925|title=12 Real Haunted Places in Philippines that Will Terrify the Hell Out of You|date=8 July 2015|work=TripZilla|accessdate=14 August 2016}}</ref>
===[[La Union]]=== <!-- Note to editors: There is consensus that entries must cite external references or they will be removed. Entries should also be in alphabetical order. --> * '''Pindangan Ruins''' ([[San Fernando, La Union]]).<ref name="HauntedAmericaTours" /><ref name="Inquirer 1">{{Cite news|author=Pastor, Pam|title=Spooky places in the Philippines|url=http://lifestyle.inquirer.net/133275/spooky-places-in-the-philippines|accessdate=31 July 2016|publisher=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]|date=26 October 2013}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|author=Smitten, Get|url=http://pumpdown.com/20-most-haunted-places-in-the-philippines/14/|title=20 Most Haunted Places in the Philippines - Page 14 of 20|date=31 October 2015|work=PumpDown|accessdate=7 August 2016}}</ref>
===[[Laguna (province)|Laguna]]=== <!-- Note to editors: There is consensus that entries must cite external references or they will be removed. Entries should also be in alphabetical order. --> [[File:Baker Hall.JPG|thumb|The Baker Memorial Hall of the UPLB.]] * '''[[University of the Philippines]] [[University of the Philippines Los Baños|Los Baños Campus]]''': A witness to the [[World War II|Second World War]] and the Japanese occupation. The [[Baker Memorial Hall]] was used as an internment camp of around 2,500 American and allied POWs and civilians 1943–1945 and headquarters for the Imperial Japanese forces stationed in Los Banos, Laguna. Believers claim of garrotted ghosts in the building. Another area of paranormal activity is a footbridge near the [[University of the Philippines Los Baños College of Engineering and Agro-Industrial Technology|UPLB CEAT]] (destroyed by [[Typhoon Milenyo]] in 2006) and Pili Drive.<ref name="HauntedAmericaTours" /><ref name="Buzzfeed2016" /><ref name="Inquirer 1" /><ref name="GhoststoriesWorld">{{Cite web|url=http://www.ghoststoriesworld.com/haunted-houses-in-philippines/haunted-up-los-banos|title=Haunted U.P. Los Banos, ghost and mythology side by side|date=|work=GhostStoriesWorld|accessdate=31 July 2016}}</ref>
===[[Pampanga]]=== <!-- Note to editors: There is consensus that entries must cite external references or they will be removed. Entries should also be in alphabetical order. --> * '''[[Clark Air Base|Clark Air Base Hospital]]''': Considered as the most haunted location in the Philippines, as it served as an asylum to the wounded (and dying) American soldiers during the [[World War II|Second World War]] and the subsequent [[Vietnam War]]. [[Ghost Hunters International]] visited the hospital in 2009, and confirmed the paranormal activities in the site. It is said to believe that people who visit the hospital and sleep within 8 hours after the visit, experience nightmares and intense lucid dreaming for a week.<ref name="Rappler">{{cite news|author=Ramoran, Carol|title=Ghost hunting in the PH? Here are 7 places|url=http://www.rappler.com/life-and-style/travel/ph-travel/42383-ghost-hunting-ph-7-places|accessdate=30 July 2016|publisher=Rappler|date=29 October 2013}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|author=|url=http://www.journal.com.ph/editorial/mysteries/visit-if-you-dare-the-5-most-haunted-places-in-the-philippines|title=Visit if you dare: The 5 most haunted places in the Philippines|date=13 January 2015|work=Journal Online|accessdate=14 August 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://ph.omg.yahoo.com/news/haunted-clark-air-base-hospital-in-new-tv-documentary-095324458.html |title=Haunted Clark Air Base hospital in new TV documentary|work=Yahoo! OMG |accessdate=20 August 2013}}</ref>
===[[Quezon]]=== <!-- Note to editors: There is consensus that entries must cite external references or they will be removed. Entries should also be in alphabetical order. --> * '''Herrera Mansion''': Also known as the '''Old Stone House''', it is widely considered the oldest house of [[Tiaong]], [[Quezon]]. It was designed by Tomás Mapua in 1920. Its original owners were Isidro and Juliana Herrera, but has been abandoned for many years ago and is now deteriorating due to decades of disuse. Believers claim of ghosts from the [[Japanese occupation of the Philippines|Japanese era]].<ref name="Buzzfeed2016">{{cite web|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/isabellelaureta/haunted-places-philippines |title=17 Haunted Places In The Philippines That Aren't For The Faint Of Heart |author=Laureta, Isabelle |date=18 October 2016 |publisher=[[BuzzFeed]] |accessdate=4 November 2017}}</ref><ref name="CNNPhConjuring" /><ref>{{Cite web|author=Smitten, Get|url=http://pumpdown.com/20-most-haunted-places-in-the-philippines/2/|title=20 Most Haunted Places in the Philippines - Page 2 of 20|date=31 October 2015|work=PumpDown|accessdate=7 August 2016}}</ref> * '''[[Mount San Cristobal]]''': A mountain located in the municipality of [[Dolores, Quezon|Dolores]]. Believing natives claim that it emanates negative energy. It is the so-called 'evil' foil to the holy Mt. Banahaw nearby.<ref>{{Cite web|author=Henares, Ivan|url=http://www.pinoymountaineer.com/2007/09/mt-cristobal-1470.html|title=Mt. Cristobal (1,470+)|date=23 September 2007|work=PinoyMountaineer|accessdate=14 August 2016}}</ref>
==Visayas==
===[[Antique (province)|Antique]]=== * '''Evelio B. Javier Freedom Park''': Located in front of the provincial capitol in the capital municipality of [[San Jose de Buenavista, Antique|San Jose de Buenavista]], it was where former provincial governor [[Evelio Javier]] was assassinated in 1986.<ref name="HauntedAmericaTours" />
===[[Cebu (province)|Cebu]]=== <!-- Note to editors: There is consensus that entries must cite external references or they will be removed. Entries should also be in alphabetical order. --> [[File:Museo Sugbu.jpg|thumb|Museo Sugbo, formerly a prison (as "''Cárcel de Cebú''")]] * '''Casa Gorordo Museum''': Located in [[Cebu City]], it previously served as the family residence of Juan Gorordo, the first Filipino bishop of the Philippines. He died in the master's bedroom in 1934. Believers, however, claim of a female specter who is said to be the ghost of one of Gorordo's spinster sisters.<ref name="choosePHCebu5"/><ref name="sunstarcebu5"/> * '''[[Cebu Normal University]]''': Located in [[Cebu City]], the university served as a garrison during the [[Japanese occupation of the Philippines|Japanese era]].<ref name="sunstarcebu5"/> * '''Escario Pension House''': A four-storey building located on Escario Street in [[Cebu City]]. Believers claim that it is haunted; stories maintain that monthly a worker perished during its construction.<ref name="PhilStarHauntedP"/><ref name="choosePHCebu5"/> * '''[[Fort San Pedro]]''': A historical military fort located in [[Cebu City]], it is claimed by believers to be haunted.<ref name="sunstarcebu5"/> * '''Lambusan Public Cemetery''': Located in Barangay Lambusan, [[San Remigio, Cebu|San Remigio]], it is situated in one of the poorest areas of the northern sector of the province. Several of the remains of the deceased were reportedly piled in a common area, as their families and relatives had no more enough money to pay for the yearly rent of the tombs. Ghost sightings in the cemetery have been reported by believers.<ref name="PhilStarHauntedP"/><ref name="choosePHCebu5"/> * '''[[Museo Sugbo]]''': It is claimed by believers to be haunted, as it was formerly a prison during the [[History of the Philippines (1521–1898)|Spanish colonial period]] (as the ''Cárcel de Cebú'') and the Japanese occupation of the Philippines.<ref name="sunstarcebu5"/> * '''Villalon Mansion''': located at the Capitol Site in [[Cebu City]], it was once the residence of an affluent Cebuano family. Believers now claim of paranormal activities in the now-off-limits site, including a white lady.<ref name="PhilStarHauntedP"/><ref name="choosePHCebu5">{{cite web|url=http://www.choosephilippines.com/go/heritage-sites/1986/cebu-haunted-places-ghost-hunting/ |title=5 Haunted Places in Cebu Perfect for Ghost Hunting |website=Choose Philippines. Find. Discover. Share. |publisher=[[ABS-CBN Corporation]] |author=Piccio, Belle |date=1 November 2014 |accessdate=13 November 2017}}</ref><ref name="sunstarcebu5">{{cite web|url=http://www.sunstar.com.ph/cebu/feature/2016/10/31/5-hair-raising-places-cebu-city-506239 |title=5 hair-raising places in Cebu City |website=SunStar |publisher=SunStar Publishing, Inc. |author=Abayon, Crischellyn D. |date=28 October 2016 |accessdate=13 November 2017}}</ref>
===[[Iloilo]]=== * '''[[Central Philippine University]]''': Said by believers to be haunted due to the atrocities committed by the Japanese in the place during World War II. Many Americans who founded the University were killed by the Japanese troops.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.panaynews.net/cpu-most-haunted/ |title=CPU most haunted? |publisher=Panay News Philippines |author=Albay, Rhick Lars Vladimir |date=28 October 2017 |accessdate=12 November 2017}}</ref>
===[[Negros Oriental]]=== * '''[[Silliman University]]''': A prestigious Presbyterian institution located in [[Dumaguete]], the institution is reported to be haunted. It was used as a station for Japanese forces during the Second World War. Notable haunted structures include the Katipunan Hall as well as three dormitory buildings; Edith Carson Hall, Channon Hall, and Doltz Hall. Channon Hall was used by the Japanese Kempeitai as their headquarters and torture chamber while Katipunan Hall was formerly the Dumaguete Mission Hospital and the main hospital of Silliman as well as the general hospital of the entire area surrounding Dumaguete and its border towns.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/lifestyle/content/542691/the-ghosts-of-silliman-university/story/ |title=The ghosts of Silliman University |publisher=[[GMA Network|GMA News Online - GMA Network]] |author=Cabristante, Raffy |date=31 October 2015}}</ref>
===[[Siquijor]]=== <!-- Note to editors: There is consensus that entries must cite external references or they will be removed. Entries should also be in alphabetical order. --> * '''[[Siquijor]]''': An [[Provinces of the Philippines|island-province]] in [[Central Visayas]], has been commonly associated with mystic traditions that the island's growing tourism industry capitalizes on. Its ties to [[faith healing|faith healers]] and [[Magic (paranormal)|sorcery]] attracts and repulses visitors at the same time.<ref>{{Cite web|author=Bolido, Linda|url=http://www.mysiquijor.com/articles/WhosAfraidofSiquijor.htm/|title=Who's afraid of Siquijor?|date=24 October 2004|work=Philippine Daily Inquirer|accessdate=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050125110138/http://mysiquijor.com/articles/WhosAfraidofSiquijor.htm/ |archivedate=25 January 2005}}</ref>
==Mindanao==
===[[Davao del Sur]]=== <!-- Note to editors: There is consensus that entries must cite external references or they will be removed. Entries should also be in alphabetical order. --> [[File:Old Davao, Philippines Airport.jpg|thumb|Davao International Airport's former terminal buildings, which still stand today.]] * '''[[Ateneo de Davao University]] - Matina campus''': The campus is situated on site of a [[World War II|wartime]]-era [[Imperial Japanese Army|Japanese]] airfield. Believing students, faculty, staff, and security personnel claim of ghosts of Japanese soldiers and of deceased students haunting the campus.<ref name="choosePHDavao">{{cite web|title=Haunted Spots in Davao |url=http://www.choosephilippines.com/specials/lists/818/haunted-spots-in-davao |date=29 October 2013 |website=Choose Philippines. Find. Discover. Share.|publisher=[[ABS-CBN Corporation]] |accessdate=12 November 2013}}</ref> * '''[[Francisco Bangoy International Airport]]''': The former terminals of [[Davao City]]'s main airport in Sasa district is now the home of several homeless families. Those believing occupants claim it is haunted by the deceased victims of the March 2003 bombing that killed 21 people.<ref>{{cite news|title=Haunted airports, coffins for the living in southern PHL? |url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/236719/hashtag/haunted-airports-coffins-for-the-living-in-southern-phl |date=27 October 2011 |publisher=[[GMA Network]] |accessdate=30 November 2017}}</ref> * '''Palm Drive''': A short road in Buhangin district of [[Davao City]] whose south end is to the west of SSS Bajada and Southern Philippine Medical Center. Believers claim it is haunted by a brown lady said to be a housemaid of one of the residences along the street who was murdered during a robbery attempt.<ref name="choosePHDavao"/> * '''Talomo Beach''': A row of retreat houses along the said beach in [[Davao City]] are said by believers to be haunted by children who drowned along the shores of the beach.<ref name="choosePHDavao"/>

[[education]] |provider = [[NASA]] |url = http://www.nasa.gov/nasaedge }} '''NASA EDGE''' is a [[video podcast]] which explores different missions, technologies and projects developed by [[NASA]]. The program was released by NASA on March 18, 2007, and {{as of|2010|06|lc=on}}, there have been 53 vodcasts produced. ==Description== NASA EDGE is a [[public outreach]] vodcast sponsored by NASA's Exploration Systems Mission Directorate and based out of the Exploration and Space Operations Directorate at [[Langley Research Center]] in [[Hampton, Virginia|Hampton]], [[Virginia]]. NASA EDGE takes an [[insider]]s look at current projects and technologies from NASA facilities around the [[United States]], and is depicted through personal interviews, on-scene broadcasts, [[computer animation]]s, and personal interviews with top scientists and engineers at NASA. The show explores the contributions NASA has made to society as well as the progress of current projects in materials and space exploration. NASA EDGE vodcasts can be downloaded from the NASA website and from [[iTunes]]. ==Cast and crew== * Chris Giersch - host * Blair Allen - co-host and senior producer{{cite news |url=http://www.nasa.gov/centers/langley/news/researchernews/snapshot_ballen.html |title=Center Snapshot – Blair Allen |work=The Researcher News |location=Langley Research Center |first=Denise |last=Adams |date=September 7, 2007 |accessdate=June 10, 2010}} * Franklin Fitzgerald - news anchor and "[[everyman]]" * Jaqueline Mirielle Cortez - special co-host * Ron Beard - director and "set therapist" * Don Morrison - audio/video engineer ==Reception== In its first year of production, the show was downloaded over 450,000 times. {{As of|2010|02}}, the average download rate is more than 420,000 per month, with over one million downloads in December 2009 and January 2010.{{cite news |url=http://www.nasa.gov/centers/langley/news/researchernews/rn_NASAEdge10.html |title=Going Where No NASA Show Has Gone Before |work=The Researcher News |location=Langley Research Center |first=Denise |last=Lineberry |date=February 11, 2010 |accessdate=June 10, 2010}} ==Interactive projects== [[File:NASA EDGE Orion Pad Abort 1 White Sands Missile Range.jpg|thumb|200px|NASA EDGE broadcasting live from [[White Sands Missile Range]] in 2010]] NASA and the NASA EDGE have developed interactive programs designed to complement the vodcast. The Lunar Electric Rover App allows users to drive a simulated [[Lunar Electric Rover]] between objectives, and provides information about and images of the vehicle.{{cite web |url=http://www.nasa.gov/multimedia/podcasting/nasaedge/iphone.html |title=NASA Lunar Electric Rover App for iPhone and iPod Touch |work=NASA.gov |first=Bob |last=Allen |date=February 26, 2010 |accessdate=June 9, 2010}} The NASA EDGE Widget provides a [[graphical user interface]] for accessing NASA EDGE vodcasts, image galleries, and the program's Twitter feed, as well as a live NASA news feed.{{cite web |url=http://www.nasa.gov/multimedia/podcasting/nasaedge/widget.html |title=NASA EDGE Widget |work=NASA.gov |first=Bob |last=Allen |date=March 23, 2010 |accessdate=June 9, 2010}} ==See also== *[[NASA TV]] *[[NASAcast]] *[[NASA 360]] *[[NASA eClips]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.nasa.gov/nasaedge NASA EDGE website] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100612093732/http://blogs.nasa.gov/cm/newui/blog/viewpostlist.jsp?blogname=NASA%20EDGE%20BLOG NASA EDGE blog] {{NASA navbox|state=collapsed}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Nasa Edge}} [[Category:NASA TV]] [[Category:NASA online]] [[Category:Science education]] [[Category:Science podcasts]] [[Category:Video on demand]] [[Category:Video podcasts]]

{{Notability|date=February 2017}} '''New7Wonders Cities''' is the third in a series of Internet-based polls operated by the New7Wonders Foundation. Founder-President, [https://about.new7wonders.com/the-project-founder-bernard-weber-a-short-history/ Bernard Weber], is a Swiss-born Canadian filmmaker, museum curator, aviator, and explorer. Based in [[San Francisco]], [[United States]], Weber’s latest campaign to find the best cities in the world aimed to showcase the "cities that best represent the achievements and aspirations of our global urban civilization".<ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/seven-urban-wonders-of-the-world-2014-12|title=These 7 Cities Are The New 'Urban Wonders' Of The World|publisher=Business Insider|accessdate=10 August 2016}}</ref>
The global competition began{{when|date=June 2018}} with more than 1200 nominees from 220 countries. That list was reduced to 77, since there was a limit of one city per country. Then the 77 remaining cities were narrowed down by a panel of experts headed by [[Federico Mayor Zaragoza]], former director-general of [[UNESCO]], to 28 suggestions. Following the announcement of the 28 finalists, the winning seven cities were chosen by voters from around the world.<ref name="auto"/> Announced in 2011, it culminated in 2014 with the choice of the following 7 winning cities: [[Beirut]], [[Doha]], [[Durban]], [[Havana]], [[Kuala Lumpur]], [[La Paz]] and [[Vigan]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.new7wonders.com/en/cities|title=New7Wonders Cities|publisher=|accessdate=27 April 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150109160159/https://www.new7wonders.com/en/cities|archivedate=9 January 2015|df=}}</ref>
It follows [[New7Wonders of the World]] and [[New7Wonders of Nature]].

The '''non-monetary economy''' represents work such as household labor, care giving and civic activity that does not have a monetary [[Value (economics)|value]] but remains a vitally important part of the [[economy]].<ref name="Cahn">{{cite journal|last=Cahn|first=Edgar S.|title=The Non-Monetary Economy|pages=1–8|url=http://timebanks.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/08/Non-MonetaryEconomy.pdf}}</ref> While labor that results in monetary compensation is more highly valued than unpaid labor, nearly half of American productive work goes on outside of the [[market economy]] and is not represented in production measures such as the [[Gross Domestic Product|GDP]].<ref name="Cahn" />
==Function== The non-monetary economy undertakes tasks that benefit society (whether through producing services, products, or making investments) that the monetary economy does not value.<ref name="Seyfang">{{cite journal|last=Seyfang|first=Gill|title=Working Outside the Box: Community Currencies, Time Banks and Social Inclusion|journal=Journal of Social Policy|date=January 2004|volume=33|issue=1|pages=49–71|doi=10.1017/S0047279403007232}}</ref>
The non-monetary economy makes the [[labor market]] more inclusive by valuing previously ignored forms of work.<ref name="Seyfang" />{{examples|date=September 2018}} Some acknowledge the non-monetary economy as having a moral or socially conscious philosophy that attempts to end [[social exclusion]] by including poor and unemployed individuals, providing economic opportunities and access to services and goods.<ref name="Peacock">{{cite journal|last=Peacock|first=Mark S.|title=The Moral Economy of Parallel Currencies: An Analysis of Local Exchange Trading Systems|journal=American Journal of Economics and Sociology|date=15 November 2006|volume=65|issue=5|pages=1059–1083|doi=10.1111/j.1536-7150.2006.00491.x}}</ref> Community-based and [[grassroots]] movements encourage the community to be more participatory, thus providing a more democratic economic structure.<ref name="Cahn" />
== Forms of the non-monetary economy ==
=== Core (or social) economy === The ''social economy'' refers to the space between public and private sectors occupied by civil society, including community organizations, volunteering, social enterprises, and cooperatives. The social economy represents “a wide family of initiatives and organisational forms — i.e. a hybridisation of market, non-market (redistribution) and non- monetary (reciprocity) economies”.<ref name="Seyfang 2">{{cite web|last1=Seyfang|first1=Gill|title=Time Banks and the Social Economy: Exploring the UK Policy Context|url=http://www.cserge.ac.uk/sites/default/files/edm_2006_01.pdf|website=www.cserge.ac.uk|publisher=CSERGE}}</ref> Rather than being fringe activities at the margins of the formal economy, this amounts to a significant level of activity: The "civil society" sector of the United Kingdom employs the equivalent of 1.4 million full-time employees (5% of the economically active population) and benefits from the unpaid efforts of the equivalent of 1.7 million full-time volunteers (5.6% of the economically active population), and contributes 6.8% of [[GDP]].<ref name="Seyfang 2" />
[[Edgar S. Cahn]] developed the concept of the ''core economy'' to describe the informal social networks that he considered the bedrock of society, which he felt were eroding as monetary economies de-legitimized them. The core economy as he defined it consists of social capital,{{when defined as|date=September 2018}} and generates collective efficacy that's of critical importance to the core economy.
''Collective efficacy'' refers to the effectiveness of informal mechanisms by which residents themselves achieve public order. More specifically, this is the shared vision or fusion of shared willingness of residents to intervene and create social trust (the sense of engagement and ownership of public spaces), intervening in the lives of other residents to counter crime, increase voting, or encourage residents to recycle. These informal mechanisms are what he{{who|date=September 2018}} calls ''social capital'', a public good provided by citizens who participate to build up their communities (from raising children and taking care of the elderly to volunteer work). This kind of work is essential{{according to whom|date=September 2018}} to a democratic and stable society.
Unlike a market economy, the core economy relies on specialization reinforced by a "do-it-yourself" attitude that “Builds self-esteem and a voluntary interdependence that replaces involuntary dependence that comes w/ industrial and market specialization”<ref name="Cahn" /> and where self-sufficiency is based upon interdependent family or community units (instead of a market economy's atomized individual). This model reduces or eliminates the involuntary dependence that comes with the market economy's strict division of labor. It also focuses on alternative distribution mechanisms to pricing, using instead normative considerations like need, fairness, altruism, moral obligation, or contribution.<ref name="Cahn" />
Collective efficacy and social capital are central to two very successful examples of civic-based, non-monetary economies: [[time banks]] and local exchange trading systems ([[LETS]]). These work systems provide alternative forms of currency, earned through time spent in directly serving the community, e.g. working in the community garden, recycling, repairing leaky faucets, babysitting. These units of time can be used to ask other members of work systems to do jobs they need, or may act as a forum in which special jobs or needs can be communicated and traded. These systems operate to a large degree outside of the monetary economy, though do not negate the importance of a monetary economy or seek a return to systems of barter.<ref name="Peacock" />
=== Time banks === {{Main|Time-based currency}} A time bank is a community-based organization which brings people and local organizations together to help each other, utilizing previously untapped resources and skills, valuing work which is normally unrewarded, and valuing people who find themselves marginalized from the conventional economy.<ref name="Seyfang 2" /> These are things that family or friends might normally do for each other, but in the absence of supportive reciprocal networks, the time bank recreates those connections. These interactions are based upon the exchange of hours spent on an activity, where [[time dollars]] are the unit of measure/ currency. They are traded for hours of labour, and are redeemable for services from other members.<ref name="Afshar">{{cite web|last1=Afshar|first1=Anna|title=Giving and Receiving in the Nonmonetary Economy: Time Banks|url=https://www.bostonfed.org/commdev/c&b/2005/fall/nonmonetary.pdf|website=www.bostonfed.org|publisher=Federal Reserve Bank of Boston}}</ref>
=== Community building === In 1998, Redefining Progress estimated that housework amounted to $1.911 trillion, roughly one-fourth of the U.S. GDP that year.<ref name="Cahn" /> As of 2010, the Bureau of Economic Analysis found that household work, if tracked, would increase the GDP by 26%.<ref>{{cite web|last=Bureau of Economic Analyses|title=What is the Value of Household Work?|url=http://blog.bea.gov/2012/06/11/household-work/|publisher=U.S. Dept. of Commerce}}</ref> More than a decade later, household work continues to provide a key source of foundational support to the domestic economy. Such household work includes cleaning, cooking, care giving, and educating children.
There may be a [[closed household economy]], where a specific (perhaps familial) group of individuals benefits from the work performed.
In extreme cases of survival, the open nature of the household economy is most evident. Food, clothing, toiletries, and basic necessities were often shared or exchanged amongst war-torn, impoverished families in East Europe post-communism.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Smith|first=Adrian|title=Culture/Economy and Spaces of Economic Practice: Positioning Households in Post- Communism|journal=Transactions of the Institute of British Geographers|year=2002|volume=27|issue=2|pages=232–250|jstor=3804544|doi=10.1111/1475-5661.00051}}</ref> Cooking, cleaning, clothes-making, and forms of work may seem to be intuitively thought of as work. An Australian study (1992) determined that an estimated 380 million person-hours per week were spent on these types of unpaid activities, compared to 272 million hours per week at paid work.<ref name="Iron">{{cite journal|last=Ironmonger|first=D. S.|title=Counting Outputs, Capital Inputs and Caring Labor: estimating Gross Household Product|journal=Feminist Economics|year=1996|volume=2|issue=3|pages=37–64|doi=10.1080/13545709610001707756}}</ref>
A large portion of these hours can be attributed to nurturing. Nurturing can take two forms, in terms of raising children and nursing the sick, elderly, and infirm, both still usually expected from women and girls.<ref name="Iron" /> Children represent not only a product of a household but an asset to the community as a whole. In the home, kids may provide help in the form of chores and so are an asset. In a greater sense, children are a public good: an investment in which time, energy, and money are spent so that they can become stable adults who share in reducing national debt and contributing to Social Security, thus a public good.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Folbre|first=Nancy|title=Children as Public Goods|journal=The American Economic Review|date=May 1994|volume=84|issue=2|jstor=2117807}}</ref> Aschildren mature and learn, they have the potential to benefit society in whatever profession or products they eventually produce.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Vila|first=Luis E.|title=The Non-Monetary Benefits of Education|journal=European Journal of Education|year=2000|volume=35|issue=1|pages=21–32|jstor=1503615|doi=10.1111/1467-3435.00003}}</ref>
The products and services produced within a home are open to the non-market economy at large. Society as a whole benefits from this unpaid work, whether in an immediate manner or a more abstract, macro scale.
The other form of home-based nurturing also serves benefits society as a whole. ''Care giving'' provides assistance for those who are elderly, disabled, suffering terminal illness or chronic illness, or are generally frail or in need of assistance. Someone who cares for someone in any of these positions is a [[caregiver]]. This is largely provided unpaid by friends or family of the patient.
Care giving often exceeds the nursing tasks that come with caring for someone who is ill or recovering from surgery. Often, caregivers also must maintain the dwelling, provide meals, and interact with medical providers and doctors, among other responsibilities. Nearly 80% of labor that keeps seniors out of nursing homes is unpaid labor by families.<ref name="Cahn" />
In 1997, the value of work produced by caregivers was estimated at $196 billion. The figure was $375 billion for 2007.<ref name="WM">{{cite journal|last=White-Means|first=S. I.|author2=Zhiyong, D. |title=Valuing the Costs of Family Caregiving: Time and Motion Survey Estimates|journal=Consumer Interests Annual|year=2012|volume=58|pages=1–8|url=http://www.consumerinterests.org/pdffiles/2012-conference/2012-54%20Valuing%20the%20Costs%20of%20Family%20Caregiving%20-%20Time%20and%20Motion%20Survey%20Estimates.pdf}}</ref> At the time, only $32 billion was spent on formal health care and $83 billion spent on nursing home care by the federal government.<ref name="Arno">{{cite journal|last=Arno|first=P. S.|author2=Levine, C. |author3=Memmott, M. M. |title=The Economic Value of Informal Care Giving|journal=Health Affairs|year=1999|volume=18|issue=2|pages=182–188|doi=10.1377/hlthaff.18.2.182|url=http://content.healthaffairs.org/content/18/2/182.full.pdf}}</ref> According to these statistics, only half as much money is spent on nursing and home health care as is necessary. These numbers do not take into account the financial burden as well as [[emotion work]] that is an inescapable part of this work.
The same research estimated that in 1997 caregivers would have received $8.18 as the hourly wage.<ref name="Arno" /> As of May 2013, the hourly wage was estimated at $9.14 when averaging the minimum wage in Florida<ref>{{cite web|last=United States Dept. of Labor|title=Minimum Wage Laws in the States - January 1, 2013|url=http://www.dol.gov/whd/minwage/america.htm#Florida}}</ref> and the median wage for Home Health Aides.<ref>{{cite web|last=Bureau of Labor Statistics|title=Occupational Employment and Wages, May 2012: 31-1011 Home Health Aides|url=http://www.bls.gov/oes/current/oes311011.htm}}</ref> Caregiving requires a large dedication, as much as 22 to 70 hours a week. An estimated 25.8 million people as of 1997 performed these tasks.<ref name="Arno" />
Caregiving has a disproportionate affect on women and white households.<ref name="WM" /> The cost of caregiving is exorbitant, nearly five times what [[Medicaid]] would have spent on long-term care, meaning only wealthy families can afford to do this type of in-home care. The intersection of class and race in this phenomenon is an important place to explore as less advantaged families will have to rely on government care, potentially at the risk of having less quality care. These statistics also highlight a differential effect on women, showing that women disproportionately do caregiving work.<ref name="WM" />
Valuing all work changes perceptions of what constitutes valuable work. Acknowledging a non-monetary economy may change the ways in which the unemployed, poor, women, and other stigmatized persons’ work is valued. It can allow citizens to see their community as a more cohesive, intertwined system that deserves their time and energy. Exploring this economy also exposes numerous areas of help that do not have enough support from the public and private sectors. Education and caregiving in particular highlight were assistance is needed and often not provided.
=== Barter economies === {{Main article|Barter}} Barter economies also constitute an important form of non-monetized interaction, although for the most part this kind of interaction is viewed{{by whom|date=September 2018}} largely as a temporary fix as an economic system is in transition. It is also usually considered a side effect of a tight monetary policy such as in a liquidity crisis, like that of 1990s Russia where barter transactions accounted for 50 percent of sales for midsize enterprises and 75 percent for large ones.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Barry|first1=Ellen|title=Have Car, Need Briefs? In Russia, Barter Is Back|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/02/08/world/europe/08barter.html?ref=todayspaper&_r=0|work=New York Times|agency=New York Times|publisher=New York Times|date=7 February 2009}}</ref>
== Policy implications == The UK in particular has been targeted by the government since the New Labor administration of the mid-1990s onwards—the social economy has been developed as a means of delivering effective public services, and mobilizing active citizenship. In 2002, for example, the Department for Trade and Industry (DTI) 2002 launched the Strategy for Social Enterprise to develop “the government’s vision … of dynamic and sustainable social enterprise strengthening an inclusive and growing economy.” The intent of the Strategy was to create an enabling policy environment for social enterprise, to make social enterprises better businesses, and to establish the value of social enterprise, in order that the sector may help to deliver on a range of policy agendas: productivity and competitiveness; contributing to socially inclusive wealth creation; neighborhood regeneration; public service reform; and developing an inclusive society and active citizenship.<ref name="Seyfang 2" />
However, by and large current policy does not reflect the implications of a system that does not validate actions that transmit community values, provide support, generates consensus, etc. These actions in the past were subsidized by cheap or free labor derived from subordinate groups, like women and ethnic or racial minorities, who as a result of entering the workforce to receive monetary validation negate these positive public goods.<ref name="Cahn" />
The biggest issue that time bank coordinators face, as a result, is funding. Time banks do not rely on volunteers, but require financial support — to pay the time broker’s salary, for a publicly accessible drop-in office, for marketing costs — to successfully attract socially excluded people in deprived neighborhoods. While many UK time banks have been supported by grant funding from the National Lottery, over time it becomes harder to secure ongoing funding, or to increase the funding available for time banks overall, and established projects close while new ones are begun elsewhere.<ref name="Seyfang 2" />
=== United States time banks and the IRS === Organizations that administer time banks, barter networks, or currencies may register for tax-exempt status under section [[501(c)(3)]] as non-profit organizations working to benefit the community.<ref name="SELC">{{cite web|title=Tax Exemption for Organizations That Administer Time Banks, Barter Networks, or Currencies|url=http://www.communitycurrencieslaw.org/choice-of-entity-and-tax-exemption/|website=www.communitycurrencieslaw.org|publisher=SELC}}</ref> The IRS has recognized some time banks as tax exempt; it is harder to obtain exemptions for a barter network or local currency, as they are harder to prove as operating purely on a basis of service to the community.
Being a time bank alone does not enable an organization to obtain tax exemption under 501(c)(3).<ref>{{cite web|last1=Cahn|first1=Edgar|title=What About Taxes?|url=http://timebanks.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/What-about-taxes_-Edgar-Cahn.pdf|website=www.timebanks.org|publisher=TimeBanks USA}}</ref> If, instead of a time bank, an organization operates a local currency or barter network, such an organization may be deemed to be operating for the private benefit of individuals, even if those individuals are members of a charitable class. An exchange platform that is designed for use of the broader community, and not specifically for a charitable class, may not be considered a tax-exempt activity for a 501(c)(3) organization.<ref name="SELC" />

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2018}} {{Further|Gas depletion|Hubbert peak theory}} {{Update|gas production having already peaked and being in short supply|date=January 2012}}
According to [[M. King Hubbert]]'s [[Hubbert peak theory]], '''peak gas''' is the point in time at which the maximum global [[natural gas]] (fossil gas) production rate will be reached, after which the rate of production will enter its terminal decline.<ref>[http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-16049551_ITM Bulls now talking up "Peak Gas" as new cause for long-term concern], Natural Gas Week, 03-06-06</ref> Natural gas is a [[fossil fuel]] formed from plant matter over the course of millions of years. It is a finite resource and thus considered to be a [[non-renewable energy]] source.
The concept of peak gas follows from [[Hubbert peak theory]], which is most commonly associated with [[peak oil]]. Hubbert saw gas, coal and oil as natural resources, each of which would peak in production and eventually run out for a region, a country, or the world. Since Hubbert's initial predictions in 1956, "the proper application of ever more powerful statistical techniques has reduced much of the uncertainty about the supply of oil and natural gas".{{cn|date = December 2017}} One view in 1997 was that Hubbert's use of an exponential decline model was statistically adequate in explaining real world data.<ref name=Cleveland1997>{{Cite journal | author1 = Cleveland, C. | author2 = Kaufmann, R. | title = Natural Gas in the US: How Far Can Technology Stretch the Resource Base? | year = 1997 | journal = Energy Journal-Cambridge Ma then Cleveland Oh- | volume = 18 | pages = 89–108 | url = http://www.bu.edu/cees/people/faculty/cutler/articles/Natural_Gas_in_US.pdf | format = PDF | publisher = ENERGY ECONOMICS EDUCATIONAL FOUNDATION INC | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080724113716/http://www.bu.edu/cees/people/faculty/cutler/articles/Natural_Gas_in_US.pdf | archivedate = 24 July 2008 | df = dmy-all }}</ref> However, longer-term experience has shown the predictions to be incorrect.
== Gas demand == [[File:Natural gas consumption.png|thumb|right|Natural gas consumption (billions of cubic meters)]]
The world gets almost one quarter of its energy from natural gas. The consumption of natural gas has nearly doubled in the last 30 years. The most important energy agencies in the world are forecasting increases in natural gas demand in the next 20 years.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.unctad.org/infocomm/anglais/gas/market.htm |title=Natural Gas Market |publisher=United Nations Conference on Trade and Development |accessdate=20 September 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080928150524/http://www.unctad.org/infocomm/anglais/gas/market.htm |archivedate=28 September 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The largest increments in future gas demand are expected to come from developing countries.
== Gas supply == [[File:World Gas Reserves.png|thumb|World natural gas proved reserves 1980-2011 (US EIA)]]
Hubbert’s original peak theory predicts that natural gas will experience three equally spaced events: first, the rate of discoveries will peak, then X years later reserves will peak, and finally X years after peak reserves, gas production will peak at the same rate as the previous peak of discoveries. For the United States, for instance, Hubbert projected that the natural gas discovery rate was peaking in 1962 at about 20 trillion cubic feet (TCF) per year. From his curves, he predicted that proved reserves would peak eight years later, in 1970, and that production would peak after another eight years, in 1978, at 20 trillion cubic feet per year, about equal to the rate of peak discoveries.<ref>M. King Hubbert, “Energy Resources,” National Academy of Sciences, Publication 1000-D, 1962, p.82.</ref>
Of the three peaks, Hubbert found the peak in discoveries most difficult to define, because of large year-to-year scatter, and the phenomenon of “reserve growth.” Initial estimates of a discovery are usually much lower than ultimate recovery, especially if the conservative estimate of [[proven reserves]] is the measure. As the discovery is drilled out, estimates rise. Sometimes estimates of recoverable oil and gas in a discovery continue to rise for many years after the discovery. To find the peak in discoveries, Hubbert backdated reserve growth to the date of field discovery.<ref>M. King Hubbert, “Degree of advancement of petroleum exploration in the United States,” AAPG Bulletin, Nov. 1967, v.51 n.11, p.2214.</ref>
=== New gas discoveries === [[File:Global Giant Gas Discoveries 1900-2000.png|thumb|300px|right|Natural gas discoveries by decade{{citation needed|date = July 2013}}]]
According to David L. Goodstein, the worldwide rate of discovery peaked around 1960 and has been declining ever since.<ref name="Goodstein2004">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nHrv78UlK7wC |title=Out Of Gas: The end of age of oil |author=David L. Goodstein |publisher=W. W. Norton & Company |year=2004 |page=128 |isbn=978-0-393-05857-4 |accessdate=30 September 2008}}</ref> Exxon Mobil Vice President, Harry J. Longwell places the peak of global gas discovery around 1970 and has observed a sharp decline in natural gas discovery rates since then.<ref name="Longwell2002">{{cite journal |url=http://www.worldenergysource.com/articles/pdf/longwell_WE_v5n3.pdf |format=PDF |title=The future of the oil and gas industry: past approaches, new challenges |author=Harry J. Longwell |date=December 2002 |publisher=[[World Energy]] |volume=5 |accessdate=30 September 2008 |issue=3 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081003081853/http://www.worldenergysource.com/articles/pdf/longwell_WE_v5n3.pdf |archivedate=3 October 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The rate of discovery has fallen below the rate of consumption in 1980.<ref name="Goodstein2004"/> The gap has been widening ever since. Declining gas discovery rates foreshadow future production decline rates because gas production can only follow gas discoveries.
Despite the reported fall in new-field discoveries, world proved reserves of natural gas have continued to grow, from 19 billion cubic meters (bcm) in 1960, 45 bcm in 1970 and 84 bcm in 1980, to a record high 200 bcm in 2012.<ref name="Annual statistical bulletin 2013">OPEC, [http://www.opec.org/library/Annual%20Statistical%20Bulletin/interactive/current/FileZ/Main.htm Annual statistical bulletin 2013].</ref> A researcher for the US [[Energy Information Administration]] pointed out that after the first wave of discoveries in an area, most oil and natural gas reserve growth comes not from discoveries of new fields, but from extensions and additional gas found within existing fields.<ref>David F. Morehouse, [ftp://eia.doe.gov/pub/oil_gas/natural_gas/feature_articles/1997/intricate_puzzle_oil_gas_reserves_growth/pdf/m07fa.pdf The intricate puzzle of oil and gas reserve growth] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100806145740/http://www.eia.doe.gov/pub/oil_gas/natural_gas/feature_articles/1997/intricate_puzzle_oil_gas_reserves_growth/pdf/m07fa.pdf |date=6 August 2010 }}, US Energy Information Administration, Natural Gas Monthly, July 1997.</ref>
Dr. [[Anthony Hayward]] CCMI, chief executive of [[BP]] stated in October 2009 that proven natural gas reserves around the world have risen to {{convert|1.2|Toilbbl|km3}} of oil equivalent, enough for 60 years' supply if consumption is non-increasing, and that gas reserves are trending upward.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/comment/ambroseevans_pritchard/6299291/Energy-crisis-is-postponed-as-new-gas-rescues-the-world.html | work=The Daily Telegraph | location=London | title=Energy crisis is postponed as new gas rescues the world | first=Ambrose | last=Evans-Pritchard | date=11 October 2009 | accessdate=22 May 2010}}</ref> A similar situation exists with oil reserves in that they have increased despite the actual declines of worldwide discoveries for decades and despite increases in consumption. BP’s former Chief Petroleum Engineer Jeremy Gilbert stated in 2007 that the growth in oil reserves "results largely from distortions created by the..reporting rules of the US Securities and Exchange Commission" that force companies to be overly conservative in their calculation of reserves, but that "even this illusory growth is unlikely to last," because fewer oil reserves are coming under the control of SEC-regulated companies.<ref>David Strahan, [http://www.energybulletin.net/node/38474 The limits to reserves growth], 18 Dec. 2007.</ref> However, since Gilbert's statement, proven reserves of both oil and gas have continued to rise, proven oil reserves increasing 23%, from 1.20 trillion barrels in 2007, to 1.48 trillion barrels in 2012.<ref name="Annual statistical bulletin 2013"/>
